we have to stay up all the time sorry so the first problem that we had
with our resiliency is because we're using kubernetes and we have multiple instances of the same we have multiple
PODS of the same service in our dispatching line you can imagine
that we doing these calculations and sending them to assets but sorry I need
water um if all three instances would be doing the calculations and sending them to the
asset the asset would know which ones to use and it could lead to weird Behavior
so this was giving us a lot of different issues or it could give us like data duplication issues data inconsistency
and extra work being done so to combat this we implemented a leader election
pattern now the way that the leader election pattern works is you have all your different instances and they are
fighting for a lease one of them will get the lease and that now determines
their the leader the others can't then interact or do anything um with anything that's locked behind this this whole
leader process and when you receive when the leader
becomes the leader they don't just keep that lead they have to consistently renew their lease otherwise it expires
and another instance takes over and the way we did this was cuz we're using kubernetes we just used the kubernetes
implementation used the new get package from kubernetes and it was just bit of config and that we were good to go from
that it was really easy to implement I was quite surprised to be honest and
what we decided to do in our case was we actually stopped the process from running if it wasn't the leader so we
could save on additional IO and compute resources and by doing this we gain
quite a lot of benefits so we gain fall tolerance because if the leader dies there's always someone there to take over and the the time for the new leader
to be like uh selected is very quick so we would never miss more than one dispatching cycle really we gain
consistency because you have a single leader so everything is now consistent um you also have one instance
making all the decisions so the coordination is a lot better and we reduced the resource usages because we
blocked it at the actual point of execution and not just block the messages going
out and the final problem that we faced and I want to speak to you guys about is the Dual right problem now when we were
actually coming up with the talk it was quite funny I hadn't read a lot about this problem that much before but it
feels like it's getting a lot more um attend at least on LinkedIn or it might just be a case of I was looking at and
now all of a sudden I'm seeing it more but anyway the way that the Dual right problem works is if a service receives a
certain uh like command to do some work finishes its work and it needs to Output that to two different places so in this
example Kafka and a SQL there's no way of knowing that for
example if SQL fails and you've already published a Kafka there's no way of now undoing that kfka send or vice versa if
you now trying if you save it into the database but the Kafka fails now you
have to go into the database and delete that record cuz there's no consistency as the two systems there's no link
between them there's no way to do this in a transactional fashion Um this can lead to a lot of problems so you can
have inconsistent State between your resources loss of messages duplication
of messages ordering issues and complexity in your error handling so the
way that we combed this implemented an outbox pattern now the way the outbox pattern works is once
the work is done and you save it in your database that part is all fairly similar but you save it to your entity table and
you also save it to your outbox table um and by doing this you can do it in a
transactional fashion so you can guarantee that if it ends up in the entity table it is going to be in the outbox and vice versa if anything fails
then it'll revert it won't be an either so at that point you can then have that consist
then you have a publisher that's it can either be another service but it's normally just another process within the
same service that runs it's reading your outbox consistently to make sure that
there's no new messages in there as soon as it a texts that there is something new it will then publish that to Kafka
and delete the record from your outbox so at this point you can always ensure that if something's not in your outbox
now it's on cufo so you've got that delivery guarantee now things could fail in this case your publisher could fail
um but that's fine because the record would still be in the outbox and it would still get sent there is one little
bit of a gotcha to this is that your you could publish dufka and the the delete
into the outbox could then fail so your delivery guarantee is at least
once but that's fine because of the you normally it's very good practice in your
outbox to implement and identify in it and you pass that identifier down and
any system that's ingesting that can use that to D duplicate messages and see if it's already received one or
not now after we implemented that we gain quite a lot from this and every
single one of our services that has any sort of publish is using this pattern so we got a lot of data consistency from
this we have fault tolerance because we can always guarantee if something's in the entity table it will be in the
outbox and it will get published we have transactional transactional consistency
because if it's in the entity and it if we're saving it to the DB if it fails it's not going to be either and we have
item poent messaging and it gave us scalability and performance because now our publishing
